localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
A group of observations that are recorded at the same time and record the blood pressure, pulse, temperature and other readings.
The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Generic event.
Rate of respiration.
Measurement of the pulse rate, or heart rate, and description of associated characteristics.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The heart rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the whole body temperature of the person.
Any event.
The measured body temperature (as a surrogate for the whole body).
Simple scale used as part of an assessment to measure and record a patient's responsiveness, indicating their level of consciousness. AVPU is an acronym for 'Alert', 'Voice', 'Pain', 'Unresponsive'.
The observation of the patient's responsiveness.
The patient is fully awake and alert.
The patient responds in any way to a voice stimulus.
The patient responds in any way to a pain stimulus.
The patient does not respond in any way to voice or pain stimuli.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation.  Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.
Default event.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
Method of monitoring blood gas measurements such as Spo2 and pTCO2 by indirect, currently non-invasive, means.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Measured via pulse oximetry, the saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood.

annotations.comment: spO2 is defined as the ratio of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO2) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO2 + deoxyhaemoglobin).

localizedDescriptions.en: Measured via pulse CO-oximetry, the saturation of methoxyhaemoglobin in the peripheral blood.
Measured via transcutaneous electrode oximetry, the partial pressure of oxygen in the peripheral blood.
Measured via transcutaneous electrode oximetry, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the peripheral blood.

Details of a series of oximetry readings, other than waveforms, expressed as a multimedia image or series of images. Waveforms should be recorded using the Waveform slot and associated cluster archetype.
Single word, phrase or brief description represents the clinical meaning and significance of the physical examination findings.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, if possible. For example, normal oxygen saturation or hypoxaemia.

localizedDescriptions.en: A text comment about the indirect oximetry result.
The amount of oxygen being delivered, or to be delivered, to the subject.  Assumed values of 21% O2, Fi02 of 0.21 and Oxygen flow rate of zero.
Percentage of inspired oxygen.
The patient is receiving air, equivalent to 21% O2.
The method used to delivery the oxygen.

annotations.comment: Intended to capture only simple description / terms. e.g. 'nasal prongs'. The 'Oxygen delivery detail' slot may be used for more detailed or complex recording.

localizedDescriptions.en: The site of the measurement sensor.
The type of measurement sensor used.

annotations.comment: For example: transmittal electrode; reflective electrode; clamp electrode; or strip electrode.

localizedDescriptions.en: A pulse oximetry transmittal sensor was applied.
A pulse oximetry reflective sensor was applied.
A pulse oximetry clamp sensor was applied.
A pulse oximetry strip sensor was applied.
A transcutaneous electrode sensor was applied.
The operating temperature of a transcutaneous oximeter electrode.
The date and time at which the sensor was applied. Significant for transcutaneous oximetry.
A simple score used to provide an objective indication of the degree of illness of a patient. This version follows guidance issued by the UK Royal College of Physicians.
Range category for the respiratory rate (RR) measurement of a patient.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 12 and 20 breaths/min; scored as 0 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 9 and 11 breaths/min; scored as 1 point.
The respiratory rate measurement is between 21 and 24 breaths/min; scored as 2 points.
The respiratory rate measurement is less than/equal to 8 breaths/min or greater than/equal to 25 breaths/min; scored as 3 points.
Range category for the oxygen saturation measurement of a patient.
The oxygen saturation level is greater than/equal to 96%;scored as 0 points.
The oxygen saturation level is between 94% and 95%; scored as 1 point.
The oxygen saturation level is between 92% and 93%; scored as 2 points.
The oxygen saturation level is less than/equal to 91%; scored as 3 points.
Range category depending on whether the patient is receiving supplemental oxygen.
The patient is not receiving supplemental oxygen; scored as 0.
The patient is receiving supplemental oxygen; scored as 1.
Range category for the body temperature (Temp) measurement of a patient.
The body temperature measurement is between 36.1 and 38.0 degrees Celsius; scored as 0 points.
The body temperature measurement is between 35.1 and 36.0 degrees Celsius or between 38.1 and 39.0 degrees Celsius; scored as 2 points.
The body temperature is greater than/equal to 39.1 degrees Celcius; scored as 2 points.
The body temperature is less than/equal to 35 degrees Celcius ; scored as 3 points.
Range category for the systolic blood pressure (SBP) measurement of a patient.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 111 and 219 mmHg; scored as 0 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 101 and 110 mmHg; scored as 1 point.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is between 91 and 100 mmHg; scored as 2 points.
The systolic blood pressure measurement is less than/equal to 90 mmHg or greater than/equal to 220 mmHg; scored as 3 points.
Range category for the heart rate (HR) measurement of a patient.
The heart rate measurement is between 51 and 90 beats/min; scored as 0 points.
The heart rate measurement is between 41 and 50 beats/min or between 91 and 110 beats/min; scored as 1 point.
The heart rate measurement is between 111 and 130 beats/min; scored as 2 points.
The heart rate measurement is less than/equal to 40 beats/min or greater than/equal to 131 beats/min; scored as 3 points.
Observed category for the AVPU scale rating of a patient's conscious state.
The patient is alert or awake; scored as 0 points.
The patient responds only to verbal, pain or stimulus; scored as 3 points.
The composite total score of each NEWS parameter category.
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
Classification of faeces characteristics according to the Bristol Stool Scale/Score.
A score to assess the characteristics of faeces after defaecation.

list.label: Separate hard lumps, like nuts (hard to pass)

localizedLabels.en: Separate hard lumps, like nuts (hard to pass)

localizedDescriptions.en: Stool consists of separate hard lumps, like nuts (hard to pass).
Stool is sausage-shaped, but lumpy.

list.label: Like a sausage but with cracks on its surface

localizedLabels.en: Like a sausage but with cracks on its surface

localizedDescriptions.en: Stool is like a sausage but with cracks on its surface.

list.label: Like a sausage or snake, smooth and soft

localizedLabels.en: Like a sausage or snake, smooth and soft

localizedDescriptions.en: Stool is like a sausage or snake, smooth and soft.

list.label: Soft blobs with clear cut edges (passed easily)

localizedLabels.en: Soft blobs with clear cut edges (passed easily)

localizedDescriptions.en: Stool consists of soft blobs with clear cut edges (passed easily).

list.label: Fluffy pieces with ragged edges, a mushy stool

localizedLabels.en: Fluffy pieces with ragged edges, a mushy stool

localizedDescriptions.en: Stool consists of fluffy pieces with ragged edges, a mushy stool.

list.label: Watery, no solid pieces. Entirely liquid

localizedLabels.en: Watery, no solid pieces. Entirely liquid

localizedDescriptions.en: Stool is watery, no solid pieces. Entirely liquid.
Any additional comment about the scale result.
Factors of patient state which may effect interpretation of the results.
The Waterlow Score, Pressure Ulcer Risk Assessment Tool.
Risk conferred by the sex of the subject.
The subject is male.
The subject is female.
Risk conferred by the age range of the subject.
The subject is under 14 years old.
The subject is aged between 14-49.
The subject is aged between 50-64.
The subject is aged between 65-74.
The subject is aged between 75-80.
The subject is aged over 80.
Risk conferred by the subject's build, based on a BMI calculation.
The subject's build is average : BMI 20-24.9 .
The subject's build is above average : BMI 25-29.9 .
The subject is obese : BMI over 30 .
The subject's build is below average : BMI below 20 .
Risk conferred by the subject's degree of continence.
The subject is completely continent or catheterised.
The subject is incontinent of urine.
The subject is incontinent of faeces.
The subject is incontinent of urine and faeces.
Risk conferred by the mobility level of the subject.
The subject is fully mobile.
The subject is restless and fidgety.
The subject is apathetic.
The subject's mobility is restricted.
The subject is confined to bed e.g by traction.
The subject is confined to a chair or wheelchair.
An estimate of nutritional risk based on the MST nutritional score but can make use of another compatible nutritional score.
Risk conferred by recent weight loss.
The subject has not recently lost weight.
The subject has recently lost 0.5-5kg in weight.
The subject has recently lost 5-10kg in weight.
The subject has recently lost 10-15kg in weight or the amount of weight loss is unknown.
The subject has recently lost  over 15kg in weight.
Risk conferred by the subject's appetite and eating habit.
The subject is eating normally and has a normal appetite.
The subject is eating poorly or has a poor appetite.
The nutritional score total, derived from Appetite and Weight loss scores or recorded directly from another compatible nutritional scoring system.
Category of risks assessed by skin inspection.
The skin appears healthy.
The skin appears healthy.
The skin has a tissue-paper quality.
The skin has a tissue-paper quality.
The skin is dry.
The skin is dry.
The skin is oedematous.
The skin is oedematous.
The aptient appears clammy or pyrexic.
The aptient appears clammy or pyrexic.
The skin is dicoloured - Pressure sore - Grade 1.
The skin is dicoloured - Pressure sore - Grade 1.
The skin has a frank pressure sore - Stage 2-4.
The skin has a frank pressure sore - Stage 2-4.
Category of risks conferred by tissue malnutrition.
The subject is terminally-ill and shows significant weight-loss.
The subject is terminally-ill and shows significant weight-loss.
The patent has single organ/system failure e.g. respiratory, cardiac, liver, renal.
The patent has single organ/system failure e.g. respiratory, cardiac, liver, renal.
The subject has multiple organ/system failure.
The subject has multiple organ/system failure.
The subject has peripheral vascular disease.
The subject has peripheral vascular disease.
The subject is significantly anaemic. Hb less than 8 mg/dl.
The subject is significantly anaemic. Hb less than 8 mg/dl.
The subject is a smoker.
The subject is a smoker.
Risk conferred by neurological deficit. Each identified risk can be scored between 4-6 but a maximum of 6 only can be given for the whole neurological deficit category.
The subject has diabetes, multiple sclerosis or has had a stroke.
The subject has no overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a mild overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a moderate overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a severe overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a motor or sensory deficit.
The subject has no overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a mild overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a moderate overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a severe overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a paraplegia.
The subject has no overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a mild overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a moderate overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a severe overall neurological deficit.
An overall estimate of neurological deficit. Should not be used if individual neurological deficit risks are recorded.
The subject has no overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a mild overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a moderate overall neurological deficit.
The subject has a severe overall neurological deficit.
Risk associated with major surgery or trauma.
Risks related to orthopaedic or spinal surgery.
The subject has no risk related to spinal / orthopaedic surgery.
The subject has undergone orthopaedic or spinal surgery.
Risks imparted by length of surgery.

list.label: On table < 2 hrs or not in ast 48 hrs

localizedLabels.en: On table < 2 hrs or not in ast 48 hrs

localizedDescriptions.en: The subject has had surgery more than 48 hrs ago or lasting for less than 2 hours.
The subject has had surgery within the past 48 hours lasting over 2 hours.
The subject has had surgery within the past 48 hours lasting over 6 hours.
Risk associated with medication.  Each medication can be scored between 0-4 but a total of 4 only can be given by all risks in the Medication category.
The subject is receiving cytotoxic medication.
The subject has no risk related to medication.
The subject has significant risk related to medication.
The subject is receiving high-dose or long-term steroid medication.
The subject has no risk related to medication.
The subject has significant risk related to medication.
The subject is receiving anti-inflammatory medication.
The subject has no risk related to medication.
The subject has significant risk related to medication.
Overall pressure ulcer risk related to medication. Should not be recorded if individual medication risks are used.
The subject has no risk related to medication.
The subject has significant risk related to medication.
The total summed score of all recorded individual risks.
Overall Waterlow Score.
The subject is at risk of developing a pressure ulcer.
The subject is at high risk of developing a pressure ulcer.
The subject is at very high risk of developing a pressure ulcer.
Additional narrative comment about the Score.
Issues that may affect interpretation of the score.
The version of the score used, normally recorded as the year.
